cds.title: Clinical Decision Support
modal.seizureClassificationDesc: Use this helper to determine the most likely seizure classification and suggested epilepsy type.
seizureClassifier.questionsUnavailable: Seizure classifier questions are unavailable. Please try again later.
seizureClassifier.renderError: Error showing classification questionnaire â€” please reload the page and try again.
seizureClassifier.durationUnrealistic: Duration is unrealistically high. Please verify input in seconds.
seizureClassifier.durationNote: Note: Duration > 5 minutes indicates potential Status Epilepticus or an error in observation
seizureClassifier.applyCanceled.speciali: Apply-to-form canceled: left for specialist review
seizureClassifier.applyCanceled.shePnesO: Apply-to-form canceled: clinician deferred due to SHE/PNES overlap
seizureClassifier.applyCanceled.suspecte: Apply-to-form canceled: clinician deferred due to suspected FDS
seizureClassifier.fdsApplied: FDS diagnosis applied. Specialist review is recommended for functional/dissociative seizures.
seizureClassifier.moreInfoNeeded: Please select a seizure type and at least one of awareness, PNES features, or syncope triggers before finishing.
seizureClassifier.completeMinimalQuestio: Please complete at least the seizure type, duration, and post-ictal recovery questions before finishing.
seizureClassifier.selectSeizureType: Please select a seizure type to continue.
seizureClassifier.structuralHistory.ques: History of severe head injury (with loss of consciousness >30 minutes), stroke, or CNS infection (meningitis/encephalitis)?
seizureClassifier.syncopeTriggers.questi: Before the event, was there pain/emotional stress, prolonged standing, or dizziness/lightheadedness?
seizureClassifier.movementDuration.quest: During the movement phase (shaking/flailing), how long did the motor activity last? (Epileptic motor activity is usually under 2 minutes.)
seizureClassifier.pnesFeatures.pelvicThr: Prominent pelvic thrusting or flailing of all limbs
seizureClassifier.syncopeSuspected: Rapid recovery with stress-only trigger suggests vasovagal syncope. Consider non-epileptic faint evaluation.
seizureClassifier.seizureType.question: What did the seizure look like?
seizureClassifier.seizureType.bilateralT: Stiffening then jerking - both sides of body
seizureClassifier.seizureType.focalMotor: Stiffening/jerking - started on one side or one limb
seizureClassifier.seizureType.focalImpai: Confused/dazed with blank stare or wandering
seizureClassifier.seizureType.possibleDi: Shaking/movements but could respond during event
seizureClassifier.awareness.question: Could the person respond or talk during the seizure?
seizureClassifier.auraPresent.question: Did the patient experience any warning before the seizure?
seizureClassifier.auraCheckBilateral.que: Did the patient experience any warning before the seizure (aura)?
seizureClassifier.spreadBilateral.questi: Did the seizure spread to involve both sides of the body?
seizureClassifier.spreadBilateral.no: No, stayed on one side only
seizureClassifier.staringDetails.justSta: Just blank staring, no other movements
seizureClassifier.staringDetails.withMov: With eyelid fluttering or lip movements
seizureClassifier.jerkTiming.question: When do these jerks mainly occur?
seizureClassifier.jerkTiming.morning: Mainly in the morning, within 1 hour of waking
seizureClassifier.jerkTiming.anytime: Can happen anytime during the day
seizureClassifier.jerkAssociated.questio: Has the patient also had any big seizures (tonic-clonic)?
seizureClassifier.jerkAssociated.yes: Yes, has had big seizures too
seizureClassifier.automatisms.question: Were there repetitive movements (lip smacking, fumbling, picking)?
seizureClassifier.pnesFeatures.question: Which features were present? (Select all that apply)
seizureClassifier.fallAwareness.question: During the fall, was the person conscious?
seizureClassifier.fallAwareness.consciou: Yes, aware but couldn't prevent fall
seizureClassifier.triggers.question: Any known triggers? (Select all that apply)
seizureClassifier.triggers.sleepOnset: Mainly during sleep or shortly after falling asleep
seizureClassifier.frequency.question: How often do these seizures occur?
seizureClassifier.clusterFrequency.quest: Do several events ever occur on the same night? (Clusters)
seizureClassifier.clusterFrequency.yes: Yes, multiple events on the same night

seizureVideo.dropOrBrowse: Drag & drop video here or click to browse
seizureVideo.supportedFormats: Supported formats: MP4, WebM, MOV â€¢ Maximum size: 100MB
seizureClassifier.duration.question: How long did the seizure last?
seizureClassifier.eventStereotypy.questi: Are the events you describe very similar each time (movements, duration)?
seizureClassifier.postIctal.question: After the seizure, was the person confused or sleepy?
seizureClassifier.toddParesis.question: After the event, was there temporary weakness/numbness or speech difficulty on one side (Todd's phenomenon)?
seizureClassifier.tongueBite.question: Was there tongue bite, injury, or loss of bladder control?
seizureClassifier.pnesCheck.question: During the event (select all that apply):
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.title: What is Epilepsy?
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.definit: Epilepsy is a condition where the brain sometimes sends out extra electrical signals that cause seizures.
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.whyHapp: These electrical signals are like short circuits in the brain. When they happen, your muscles shake or you lose consciousness for a short time.
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.notCont: âœ“ Epilepsy is NOT contagious - you cannot catch it from anyone.
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.notYour: âœ“ Epilepsy is NOT your fault - it's a medical condition, not something you caused.
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.prognos: âœ“ Good news: With proper medicine, 8 out of 10 people with epilepsy can have no seizures.
education.modules.epilepsyBasics.misconc: Many people think epilepsy is caused by spirits or curses - this is not true. It's a treatable medical condition just like diabetes or high blood pressure.
education.modules.medications.generic.ho: Epilepsy medicines calm down the extra electrical signals in your brain. They don't cure epilepsy, but they prevent seizures from happening.
education.modules.medications.generic.ti: These medicines take 2-4 weeks to start working properly. Don't stop them if you don't see results immediately.
education.modules.medications.generic.ty: There are many different epilepsy medicines. Your doctor chose the best one(s) for YOUR type of epilepsy.
education.modules.medications.carbamazep: Used for focal seizures (seizures that start in one part of the brain). Works well for adults.
Usually 200-400mg twice a day. Take with food to reduce stomach upset.

âœ“ Take with meals (breakfast and dinner)
âœ“ Take at same time every day
âœ“ Swallow whole - don't chew
âœ— Don't skip doses

First 2 weeks: dizziness, sleepiness, blurred vision - these usually improve.
Less common: rash, swollen gums, liver problems.
âš ï¸ STOP and call doctor immediately if: severe rash, jaundice (yellow skin), severe fever.

This medicine can make hormonal contraceptives less effective. If you use birth control, tell your doctor.
Can increase sun sensitivity - use sunscreen (SPF 30+).
education.modules.medications.levetirace: Used for both focal AND generalized seizures. Works well for all types. Generally well-tolerated.
Usually 500-1000mg twice a day. Can take with or without food.

âœ“ Can take anytime with or without meals
âœ“ Take at same time every day
âœ“ Tablet or liquid form available
âœ— Don't stop suddenly

Rare: mood changes, irritability, tiredness. These usually improve within weeks.
Small dose increase helps reduce initial tiredness.

âœ“ No interaction with contraceptive pills.
âœ“ Safe in pregnancy (safer than some other medicines).
âœ“ Doesn't need special liver or kidney tests.
education.modules.medications.clobazam.u: Given AS AN ADDITIONAL medicine when seizures continue despite first medicine. Not used alone.
education.modules.medications.clobazam.d: Usually 5-10mg daily. Your doctor will start with low dose and increase gradually.
education.modules.medications.clobazam.p: Your first medicine controls seizures but you still had breakthroughs. Clobazam works with your first medicine to reduce seizures further.
education.modules.medications.clobazam.s: Usually very well tolerated. Minimal side effects. Some patients feel slightly sleepy initially.
education.modules.medications.clobazam.t: âš ï¸ Effectiveness may reduce after months of use. Regular follow-ups help monitor this.
education.modules.adherence.title: Taking Your Medicines Correctly (Adherence)
education.modules.adherence.why: Taking medicines on time, every day is THE MOST IMPORTANT thing you can do. Missing even 1-2 doses can cause seizures.
education.modules.adherence.reminders:
âœ“ Set 2 alarms on your phone - one for morning, one for evening dose.
âœ“ Use a pill box labeled Mon-Tue-Wed-Thu-Fri-Sat-Sun.
âœ“ Keep medicines in a visible place at home.
âœ“ Ask family member to remind you.
education.modules.adherence.barriers: Why do people miss doses? And what to do about it:
education.modules.adherence.barrierCost: Cost too high? â†’ Get free medicines from your PHC. Don't buy from private shops.
education.modules.adherence.barrierSideE: Feeling sick from side effects? â†’ Don't stop medicines. Side effects usually improve in 2 weeks. Call your CHO for help.
education.modules.adherence.barrierForge: Forgetful? â†’ Use phone alarms + pill box. Write dose time on your calendar.
education.modules.adherence.barrierFeelB: Feeling better / no seizures? â†’ Keep taking medicines. Medicine CAUSES the good feeling. Stop medicines = seizures return.
education.modules.adherence.barriers.wor: Busy with work? â†’ Take medicines BEFORE leaving home, not later during work.
education.modules.adherence.missedDose:
What if you miss a dose?

â€¢ If less than 2 hours late: Take it immediately.
â€¢ If more than 2 hours late: Skip that dose, take next dose at normal time.
â€¢ NEVER double the next dose.
â€¢ Call your CHO for guidance.
education.modules.seizureManagement.trig: What can trigger seizures? (Even when taking medicines):

â€¢ Missed medicines (most common cause)
â€¢ Not enough sleep / staying awake all night
â€¢ Missing meals / fasting too long
â€¢ Alcohol drinking
â€¢ High stress or worry
â€¢ For women: Seizures around menstrual period
â€¢ Flashing lights (if you're sensitive)
education.modules.seizureManagement.avoi:
âœ“ Take medicines on time EVERY day
âœ“ Sleep 7-8 hours daily
âœ“ Eat regular meals
âœ“ Avoid alcohol completely
âœ“ Manage stress with relaxation
âœ“ Inform family about your triggers
education.modules.seizureManagement.duri: What to do DURING a seizure:

1. Stay calm. Seizures are scary but not dangerous if you're in a safe place.
2. Move the person to a safe area away from sharp objects / stairs.
3. Lay them on their side (prevents choking if drool comes).
4. Support their head with a pillow or cushion.
5. Look at the clock - note what time seizure started.
6. DO NOT put anything in their mouth.
7. DO NOT hold their arms/legs down - let them shake freely.
8. Stay with them until they wake up fully (can take 5-30 minutes).
education.modules.seizureManagement.afte: What to do AFTER a seizure:

1. Stay calm and reassure the person.
2. Help them to a quiet, safe place to rest.
3. Check their body for injuries (cuts, bruises).
4. Give them water to drink after they're fully awake.
5. Recovery time: 30 minutes to 4 hours (they'll feel tired and confused).
6. Don't let them drive or operate machinery for 24 hours.
7. Tell family members what happened.
education.modules.redFlags.title: When to Seek Help - URGENT
education.modules.redFlags.immediate: ðŸš¨ GO TO HOSPITAL IMMEDIATELY if:
education.modules.redFlags.immediateList:
â€¢ Seizure lasts MORE than 5 minutes (STATUS EPILEPTICUS - very dangerous)
â€¢ Person has 2-3 seizures back-to-back without waking up between them
â€¢ Difficulty breathing / purple face during seizure
â€¢ Unconscious for more than 1 hour after seizure
â€¢ Severe head injury / bleeding from head
â€¢ FIRST-TIME seizure (never had seizure before)
â€¢ Injury during seizure (broken bone, deep cut)
education.modules.redFlags.same24: âš ï¸ CALL YOUR CHO WITHIN 24 HOURS if:
education.modules.redFlags.same24List:
â€¢ Different type of seizure than usual (different movements, different feeling)
â€¢ Worsening side effects (severe rash, yellow skin, extreme tiredness, confusion)
â€¢ Unable to take medicines (vomiting, medication lost)
â€¢ Thoughts of harming yourself or others
â€¢ Pregnancy suspected or confirmed
education.modules.redFlags.nextvisit: ðŸ“‹ Tell us at NEXT VISIT (PHC appointment) if:
education.modules.redFlags.nextvisitList:
â€¢ New, mild side effects (slight dizziness, mild rash)
â€¢ Recently missed 2-3 doses
â€¢ Cost of medicines is a problem
â€¢ Name/phone number changed
â€¢ Want to change medicines
education.modules.living.title: Living Well With Epilepsy
education.modules.living.sleep:
SLEEP: Get 7-8 hours every night.
â€¢ Lack of sleep is the #2 cause of seizures (after missed medicines).
â€¢ Keep same sleep time every night (even weekends).
â€¢ If you have night seizures: Sleep on your side. Use a medical alert bracelet.
education.modules.living.work:
WORK & SCHOOL:
â€¢ Most jobs are safe (farming, teaching, shopkeeping, office work).
â€¢ AVOID: Driving heavy machinery, working at heights, swimming unsupervised.
â€¢ Tell your employer about epilepsy so they understand if you need time off.
â€¢ Discuss work safety with your CHO.
education.modules.living.pregnancy:
PREGNANCY:
â€¢ You CAN have children. Many women with epilepsy have healthy babies.
â€¢ Some medicines are safer in pregnancy than others.
â€¢ Plan pregnancy with your doctor BEFORE getting pregnant.
â€¢ NEVER STOP MEDICINES when pregnant - seizures during pregnancy are more dangerous than medicines.
â€¢ Most epilepsy medicines are safe - your doctor will choose the safest one.
education.modules.living.contraception:
CONTRACEPTION (Birth Control):
â€¢ Tell your doctor which contraception you use (some medicines reduce effectiveness).
â€¢ Safer options: IUD, sterilization, barrier methods.
â€¢ Birth control pills may be less effective - consider extra protection.
education.modules.living.driving:
DRIVING:
â€¢ Local law usually requires seizure-free for 6-12 months before driving.
â€¢ Ask your doctor when you can drive.
â€¢ Do NOT drive if having auras (warning signs) before seizures.
â€¢ Medical alert bracelet recommended.
education.modules.living.stigma:
STIGMA & SOCIETY:
â€¢ âœ“ You CAN work, marry, have children, live a normal life.
â€¢ âœ— Epilepsy is NOT a curse or spirit possession - it's medicine.
â€¢ âœ— You are NOT 'different' - many successful people have epilepsy.
â€¢ Tell close friends/family about your epilepsy so they can help during seizures.
education.modules.living.alcohol:
ALCOHOL & DRUGS:
â€¢ âœ— Avoid alcohol completely - it reduces medicine effectiveness and triggers seizures.
â€¢ âœ— Never use recreational drugs - especially dangerous interaction with epilepsy medicines.
education.modules.support.title: Your Healthcare Team
education.modules.support.cho: CHO (Community Health Officer) at your PHC:
education.modules.support.choRole:
â€¢ Gives you medicines each month
â€¢ Checks how medicines are working
â€¢ Watches for side effects
â€¢ Answers your questions about medicines
â€¢ Helps you with problems taking medicines
â€¢ Refers you to doctor if needed
education.modules.support.choVisit: Visit CHO every month for first 3 months, then every 3 months if controlled.
education.modules.support.doctorRole:
â€¢ Diagnoses epilepsy type
â€¢ Decides which medicines to use
â€¢ Reviews your progress
â€¢ Makes changes to medicines if needed
â€¢ Handles complicated cases
â€¢ Gives specialist referrals
education.modules.support.yourRoleList:
âœ“ Take medicines on time every day
âœ“ Keep all appointments
âœ“ Report new seizures or side effects
âœ“ Tell us if cost is a barrier
âœ“ Write down seizure dates/times
âœ“ Get enough sleep
âœ“ Avoid triggers
education.modules.support.scheduleText:
Month 1: 2 visits (start + check side effects)
Months 2-3: Monthly visit
If seizures controlled: Every 3 months
After 1-2 years seizure-free: Can reduce to every 6 months
education.epilepsyDefinition: Epilepsy is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent seizures
education.treatmentBenefits: With proper treatment, most people with epilepsy can live normal lives
education.takeMedicationRegularly: It's important to take medication regularly as prescribed
education.regularFollowups: Regular follow-ups help monitor treatment effectiveness
education.doNotStopSuddenly: Do not stop suddenly without consulting your doctor
education.reportSideEffects: Report any side effects to your healthcare provider
education.informFamily: Inform family and friends about seizure first aid

seizureFrequency.yearlyDesc: Yearly (not monthly) â€“ Up to 12 seizures per year
seizureFrequency.lessYearlyDesc: Less than yearly â€“ Less than 12 seizures per year
seizureFrequency.missingMedsDesc: Only on missing medicines â€“ Seizures only occur when medicines are missed
